prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

para.paratext: The transferee court has various devices whereby it may cause transferred cases to be disposed of on the merits prior to remand. The transferee court cannot consolidate transferred cases for trial with those already pending in the transferee district without entering an order transferring venue. Short of venue change, the transferee court may only order coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[1]

The court can, however, conduct a trial on a preliminary issue in bifurcated proceedings, thereby obviating remand if that trial results in a finding that is effectively binding on par ties by operation of collateral estoppel. This has been used in antitrust litigation by holding an initial trial on the liability issue and, upon a finding of violation of the Sherman Act, entry of an order collaterally estopping the defendant from contesting liability to any plaintiff.[2] This device has also been successfully used in products liability litigation to try the question of defect in a joint trial.[3] Consolidation for pretrial purposes is, of course, a regular tool of managing cases centralized cases, even without regard to disposition of them in the transferee court.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See 15 Charles Alan Wright, Arthur R. Miller & Edward H. Cooper, Federal Practice and Procedure § 3866 (4th ed. 2013). For a thorough analysis of the court's various options with respect to consolidation, see Kurtz v. Kimberly-Clark Corp., 2016 WL 6820405 (E.D. N.Y. 2016), citing in several locations David F. Herr, Annotated Manual for Complex Litigation (Fourth) (2013 edition).
This application in Gypsum Wallboard is discussed in Note, The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation and the Conduct of Multidistrict Litigation, 87 Harv. L. Rev. 1001, 1033–34 (1974).
See In re Richardson-Merrell, Inc. Bendectin Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 606 F. Supp. 715 (J.P.M.L. 1985).
See, e.g., In re Oreck Corporation Halo Vacuum and Air Purifiers Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 282 F.R.D. 486 490–91 (C.D. Cal. 2012).
